The modulus of elasticity, also known as Young's modulus, is a measure of the stiffness or resistance to deformation of a material. It is defined as the ratio of stress to strain within the proportional limit of the material, where stress is the force per unit area applied to the material and strain is the resulting deformation or elongation of the material.

The modulus of elasticity describes the ability of a material to withstand deformation when subjected to external forces. A higher modulus of elasticity indicates that the material is stiffer and less likely to deform under load, while a lower modulus of elasticity indicates that the material is more flexible and more likely to deform under load.

The modulus of elasticity is an important material property in engineering and materials science, as it is used to design and analyze structures and components subjected to external forces. For example, in designing a bridge, the modulus of elasticity of the materials used in its construction is an important consideration to ensure that the bridge can withstand the weight of traffic and other loads without deforming excessively.

It should be noted that the modulus of elasticity is only applicable within the proportional limit of a material, beyond which the material may exhibit non-linear elastic behavior or even plastic deformation. In such cases, other material properties such as yield strength and ultimate strength become more relevant for design and analysis.
